SUMMARY t Adaptation in corn is looked upon a> tin- fortuitous or nee modification or acquisition of hereditary characters or ditie- thru the favorable reaction of the crop to its environ - nt. This may occur thru, (1) mutation from an individual. is producing a new character: (2) Mendelian recombination unit characters resulting in new forms ; and (3) segregation the more suitable types present in a mixed population. Sur al of the fittest is the active selective principle. Nebraska's climate is very diversified and affords a splen - did opportunity for studying the regional adaptation of corn. Soil differences are not nearly m» great a factor in 1 1 i i — adaptation a> i> climate. I A- extremes in climatic- conditions, western Nebraska coin - ed with eastern Nebraska normally has a -ix-degree V. lower il>erature during the corn growing season. The frost-free iod is fifty days -liorter. and the precipitation one-half u at. The growing season of northern Nebraska i- four de - er- F. cooler than of southern Nebraska, and the (root-free iod i- almut twenty day- -horter. Tht Regional Adaptation of Corn in Nebraska 5 area. This >tomatal character is associated with a rather cor - responding reduction in size of epidermal cell, all of which may be ascribed to a more dwarfish development. The number of vascular bundles per unit cross-section of leaf is fairly con - stant. While some of the vegetative characters, such as total leaf area and plant weight, may reduce as much as 300 per cent, no important histological leaf characters exhibit more than 15 per cent deviation in the case of native types growing in the most adverse as compared with the most favored parts of the State. Practically speaking, adaptation with corn consists in morphological rather than in a histological reaction. As a concrete example of the foregoing adaptive reactions, the 1915 difference between home-grown native Richardson County and Kimball County corn types may be cited. These two localities represent the extremes or corn growing conditions within the State. Comparing the measurements of Richardson County corn with those of Kimball County corn, we have the following ratios: Stalk height. 100:60; ear height. 100:35; leaf area. lOOAS; stover weight. 100:49; ear weight, 100"24: grain weight, 100:90; total plant substance. 100:34; shelling per - centage. 1(K):84: leaf area, per unit dry matter, 100:100; ear length. 100*6; ear circumference, 100:81; kernel length. 100:73; leaf thickness. ]O0:JK>: thickness of upper epidermis, 100:97; thickness of lower epidermis. 100:97; number of vascular bundles per unit of cros>-section of leaf. 100:104: number of -loninta |ht x|uare millimeter of upper epidermis. 100:113, and of lower epidermis. 100:115: length ot stonia of upper epidermis, loo:s;i. and of lower epidermis. l(H):!Ki; length of epidermal cell of upfier epidermis. 100:92, and of lower epi - dermis. 100:!>7: and width of epidermal cell of upper epidermis, The immediate effect of moving corn from its native en- vironment to less favorable conditions, climate being the chief variable factor, is generally a reduction in both vegetative growth and grain production. The stunting growth effect ex - tend.- to the cell unit, which in turn is accompanied by histo - logical rhaagM tliat can not apparently l>e regarded aa of an adaptive nature. PMPARATIVE TRANSPIRATION OF EASTERN AND WESTERN CORN TYPES The preceding morphological and histological adaptation studies have indicated that the chief adaptive characteristic of dry-land short -season corn was a marked reduction in vegetative growth. There was no definite indication of favorable structural adaptive reaction, tho a somewhat shorter stomatal aperture pre - vailed. This was regarded more as a dwarfish correlation, than as a directly adaptive feature. If adaptively effective, the shorter aperture should be expected to reduce the relative amount of transpiration per unit leaf area. This is not the eaaa, a- -how n in Table 30.
